intro: Cousinia manucehrii, commonly known as the Kashmiri globemallow, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Jammu and Kashmir in India. It belongs to the family Polygonaceae, which includes plants known for their distinctive leaf shapes and often edible seeds. The plant is characterized by its tall, erect stems and clusters of small, pinkish to reddish flowers that bloom in summer. Its leaves are alternate, lance-shaped, and covered in fine hairs, which help reduce water loss in its arid habitat. Cousinia manucehrii is often found in rocky or gravelly soils at high altitudes, showcasing its adaptability to harsh environmental conditions.
